title: About
text: I’m Jack, a junior Finance and Sports Media dual major at the University of Nebraska Lincoln. I’m interested in the business side of sports and how they contribute to an effective media product.

title: The 2025 Colts are an Unexpected Cindarella Story
text:
The Indianapolis Colts in the course of one offseason have taken a team that was nearly unwatchable, to an extremely exciting offense.
Through 10 games Daniel Jones is third in the league in Passing Yards, while Jonathan Taylor is leading the league by nearly 200 Rushing Yards as he looks to win his first Offensive Player of the Year and hopefully an MVP. But those stats understate how good this team has been.
With last years team being 8-9 and incredibly boring to watch, this team already has 8 wins. With a turnaround like this fans have to wonder what changed for the colts. One statistic immediately jumps out this year compared to last for the colts, and that’s their Percentages of drives ending in scores.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)

scoring <- read_csv("ScoringDrives - Sheet1.csv")
ColtsScore <- scoring |> filter(Team == "Indianapolis Colts")
ChiefsScore <- scoring |> filter (Team == "Kansas City Chiefs")
EaglesScore <- scoring |> filter(Team == "Philadelphia Eagles")

ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=scoring, aes(x=Season, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team), color="grey") +
  geom_point(data=scoring, aes(x=Season, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=ColtsScore, aes(x=Season, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team), color="blue") +
  geom_point(data=ColtsScore, aes(x=Season, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team), color="blue") +
  geom_line(data=ChiefsScore, aes(x=Season, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team), color="red") +
  geom_point(data=ChiefsScore, aes(x=Season, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team), color="red") +
  geom_line(data=EaglesScore, aes(x=Season, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team), color="darkgreen") +
  geom_point(data=EaglesScore, aes(x=Season, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team), color="darkgreen") +geom_text(data=ColtsScore |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season + .22, y=ScoringDrives+.1, group=Team, label=Team)) + 
  geom_text(data=ColtsScore |> filter(Season == min(Season)), aes(x=Season - .22, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team, label=Team)) + 
  geom_text(data=ChiefsScore |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season + .24, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team, label=Team)) + 
  geom_text(data=ChiefsScore |> filter(Season == min(Season)), aes(x=Season - .24, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team, label=Team)) + 
  geom_text(data=EaglesScore |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season + .24, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team, label=Team)) + 
  geom_text(data=EaglesScore |> filter(Season == min(Season)), aes(x=Season - .24, y=ScoringDrives, group=Team, label=Team)) + 
    scale_x_continuous(breaks=c(2024, 2025), limits=c(2023.5,2025.5)) + 
  labs(
    x="Season", 
    y="Percentage of drives ending in scores", 
    title="NFL Offenses drives ending in scores by year", 
    subtitle="This is how the Colts compare against the past years Superbowl matchup.", 
    caption="Source: Data Provider | By Jack Dynek"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()









As we can see the colts have made a major jump. going from bottom middle of the pack. To leading the league by over 6% of drives. With a turnaround like that it’s no wonder why this team is so much more successful. Beyond just that though their success can be reflected in how many more yards they’re averaging per game.


Code
game824 <- read_csv("2024_8game.csv")
game825 <- read_csv("2025_8game.csv")


longame824 <- (game824) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols=starts_with("Offense"),
    names_to="Type",
    values_to="Yards"
  )
longame825 <- (game825) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols=starts_with("Offense"),
    names_to="Type",
    values_to="Yards"
  )


ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=longame824, aes(x=Week, weight=Yards, fill=Type)) + geom_hline(yintercept=315, color="blue") +
  coord_flip()+ 
  labs(
    x="Week", 
    y="Offensive Yards Per Game", 
    title="Colts First 8 Games on Offense in 2024", 
    subtitle="This shows how the Colts pass and rushing yards each game to start 2024.", 
    caption="Source: Data Provider | By Jack Dynek"
    ) +
    theme_minimal()









This is the start to the colts season in 2024, and through eight games they averaged 315 yards and relied heavily on the pass game, only going over 400 yards once.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=longame825, aes(x=Week, weight=Yards, fill=Type)) + 
  coord_flip()+  geom_hline(yintercept=383.33, color="blue") +
  labs(
    x="Week", 
    y="Offensive Yards Per Game", 
    title="Colts First 8 Games on Offense in 2025", 
    subtitle="This shows how the Colts pass and rushing yards each game to start 2025.", 
    caption="Source: NFL Sports Reference | By Jack Dynek"
    ) +
    theme_minimal()









This on the other hand is the 2025 Colts year. They averaged 383 yards a game and have already had four games over 400 total yards with plenty of dominant performances from both the run and pass game.
One player that has directly led to Colts passing game improving is Tyler Warren. Through eight games he already has more recieving yards than the entire Colts tight end room had last year in the entire season. His production is great against even seasoned veterans at the tight end position


Code
recieving <- read_csv("recieving_2025.csv")

terec <- recieving |>
  filter(Pos == "TE") |>
  arrange(desc(Yds))

TW <- terec |> filter(Player == "Tyler Warren")
TM <- terec |> filter(Player == "Trey McBride")

ggplot() + geom_point(data=terec, aes(x=Yds, y=Rec, size=TD )) + geom_point(data=TW, aes(x=Yds, y=Rec, size=TD),color="blue")+ geom_text_repel(data=TW, aes(x=490, y=43, label=Player))+ geom_point(data=TM, aes(x=Yds, y=Rec, size=TD),color="red") + geom_text_repel(data=TM, aes(x=480, y=50, label=Player))+
  labs(
    x="Total Recieving Yards", 
    y="Total Catches", 
    title="NFL Tight End Recieving Leaders", 
    subtitle="This is how tight ends across the league compare statistically with each other.", 
    caption="Source: NFL Sports Reference | By Jack Dynek"
    ) +
    theme_minimal()









While Tyler Warren has meant a lot for the Colts, it’s hard to argue any players impact more than Jonathan Taylor’s. He has been dominant to begin the season and leads all running backs in yards and touchdowns.This data accounts for his first 9 games prior to his dominant performance against the Falcons, but still illustrates his spectacular year.


Code
rushing <- read_csv("rushing_2025.csv")

JT <- rushing |> filter(Player == "Jonathan Taylor")
CMC <- rushing |> filter(Player == "Christian McCaffrey")

ggplot() + geom_point(data=rushing, aes(x=Yds, y=Att, size=TD )) + geom_point(data=JT, aes(x=Yds, y=Att, size=TD),color="blue")+ geom_text(data=JT, aes(x=775, y=161, label=Player)) + geom_point(data=CMC, aes(x=Yds, y=Att, size=TD),color="darkred")+ geom_text(data=CMC, aes(x=525, y=161, label=Player))+
  labs(
    x="Rushing Yards", 
    y="Rushing Attempts", 
    title="NFL Rushing Leaders", 
    subtitle="This is how NFL running backs compare statistically against each other", 
    caption="Source: NFL Sports Reference | By Jack Dynek"
    ) +
    theme_minimal()









All of these combine to show how the colts have improved to be a much better team than they were in the 2024 season and time will tell how they finish out the remainder of the year.
